reviews.review_text: The black sheep of the Final Fantasy series, Final Fantasy VIII is a game that divides opinion to this very day. Is it good? Is it bad? Does it make a lick of sense? Is Squall a sexy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? No one entirely agrees on an answer to any of these questions (except for the last one, the answer of which is YES), but I have my own take it. FFVIII is perhaps the most underappreciated games in the entire series. Much like how FFVII deconstructed JRPGs that existed up to that point, FFVIII deconstructs the wave of RPGs that followed in Final Fantasy VII's wake, mocking their tropes and characters, while at the same time telling a very unique story. FFVIII follows Squall Leonheart, a student at Balamb Garden, a military academy that trains SeeDs, a mercenary force designed for one purpose: to hunt down and destroy Sorcerresses. Squall is probably my favorite lead character in a Final Fantasy game, and that has one clear reason: he's realistic. Unlike Cloud or Zidane, he isn't a teenager who can somehow fight the forces of darkness without sweat: he's a flawed person, broken by a crappy childhood and a dehumanising education that taught him how to kill. In essence, he behaves how a real person would in his situation. Over the course of the game, we're treated to a near-constant internal monologue that tells us about the struggles he faces internally and how he deals with them. He's a great lead. The rest of the cast is more mixed, with high points being Irvine, who often reflects Squall, and Laguna, who's chipper attitude is a nice respite from the grim tones of Squall, and low points being the annoying and fairly useless Zell, the bland and boring Quistis, and the game's dumb villain, Ultimecia. The plot itself is also a bit of a mixed bag, with some really good moments offset by some really dumb ones. The battle system is a clear departure from the rest of the series too. Rather than levelling up your characters to build stats, instead, stats are built by 'junctioning' magic to various stats to increase their parameters. This is a great system, one ripe for experimentation, hampered by one thing: Drawing. Magic works like items in FF8: once you use a charge, it's gone. The only way to get magic early on is by painstakingly drawing magic from enemies: an incredibly tedious and boring prospect. It's rectified later once you get access to card refinement, but it's still a hassle. Speaking of card refinement. this game comes with a very entertaining trading card diversion called Triple Triad, and it's a blast. Simple, quick, yet endlessly addictive.   So, that's Final Fantasy VIII. Honestly, I love it, and it remains one of my favorites of the series. However, it's a very flawed game, so chances are, you may not like it. However, approach it with an open mind, and I think you'll enjoy what lies in store.

If you plan to buy this - get Roses and Wine. It's a free mod that enhances the quality of music.   Other than that - a definitive version of Final Fantasy VIII. I, personally, still find it enjoyable as it was all those years ago. Get it if you haven't already.

Why would you change a feature that allows casual players to play through at their own pace while still making random battles worthwhile, into something where people are going to be equipping Enc-None for 90% of the game. The point of that system was to make the game for everyone, if you wanted to play hardcore, you level grinded at the start and the battles became harder, enemies got new moves and so on. Now, nothing changes.****  **EDIT*** The normal monsters do level up equal to Squall's level, the Bosses/GF's don't seem to. Diablo was 7 levels lower than my whole party and Ifrit was 4 levels lower. I didn't check any other boss so far.  3. (haven't noticed the same with other summons (yet).  5. Official description of game: Really, Galbadia didn't declare war on Dollet, it attacked it in order to take the Comm. Tower. Squall and Siefer are not a part of Dollet nor is their 'Training Facility' Balamb Garden, as the name might suggest it is located elsewhere (on another continent). The person who wrote this part should be fired for not even playing the game, how can you screw up something that is explained within half an hour of gameplay.  Overall, I recommend buying the game from the playstation store. Either via a ps3 or PSP (any version) or if you don't have that then I'm sorry but this lackluster game is the closest you'll get to the origional. The mandatory account sign-up rubs me the wrong way. If we could use a star system here on Steam that would certainly cost this purchase a star. It doesn't take away from the game itself, though. I had no technical issues with the installation, account sign-up, or the game itself.  FF8 is an underrated title in the series. I see a lot of people saying it was the beginning of quality downturn for the series, and I mostly disagree. The 'draw' system for acquiring spells is a bit monotonous at times, but that's the only flaw that could have been thought out better. I may not like every feature of the game, but I chalk all of my other issues up to simple taste preference. You can't please everyone.  Where this game fares well is storytelling, and that's really what these games are known for. Relatable characters on journeys that pull you into the game, and almost make you feel as though you have a personal stake in defeating the antagonist(s). The length of the cut scenes may seem a little excessive at times, but I enjoyed the vast majority of them.  The mini-game is card-based, for those concerned with making this game last as long as possible. It isn't as repeatable long-term as Chocobos from FF7, but on the plus side you can start playing cards a lot sooner in the game, and most rare cards are attainable even if you choose to skip the task (or miss it) originally. Like I said, it's not as fun as breeding and racing Chocobo from 7, but they were never going to top that for my enjoyment anyway.  Overall it was well worth the purchase. I have the original discs for PS, so I waited until I saw a nice sale on it.. but for those who are looking to play for the first time, or play again and no longer have it on Playstation, I think it's worth the full price.

This is still one of my favorite Final Fantasy games, and the PC benefits over the PS1 are pretty nice. I love the ability to speed up the cinematics to 60 fps, which make the scenes look fantastic, although everything is moving at twice the speed, thus making it a much shorter cutscene, which is the closest thing to being able to skip it. But if you've already sunk hundreds of hours into it before, then it's definitely worth checking out, especially when it's on sale. If you havent played it before, its still definitely worth the money. The cutscenes still look good (for the time they were released, especially) and the overall game doesn't look too shabby compared to others from its time. The ability to summon GFs (basically pets) and unlock loads of skills for then as well as everyone in the party is awesome. The magic/GF/Ability junction feature is also one of my favorite implemented systems, making it much easier to help overcome more powerful opponents once you've gotten used to utilizing it. Only downside to that is that you constantly need to stock magic in order to keep your stats as buffed as possible, which can take awhile and becomes a bit tedious. But overall, the mechanics are very smooth and simple. The story is very well done too. It's enough of a driving factor to keep people who may not like grinding very much to stay interested, although there's no journal or anything of that nature to keep you focused on where to go next, which may become a problem if you decide to stop playing for a while and resume later. That's one of my only real problems with this game. Most adventure/open world games have some sort of journal or objective list in case you forget where you're supposed to go next, or at least who to talk to. That aside, I'd still highly recommend this game to just about anyone who loves the old school RPG style of game play with some unique mechanics and a good storyline.  TL;DR Buy this game. It's a great part of the FF series.

At first, this game took me a while to get into due to the strange magic and stat system as well as the general world of the game, but I ended up surprising myself by how likable it ended up being.  In this game, you can gather magic spells from enemies via battle command, and then recast the spells, or equip them onto your stats to make them increase. This felt like a very weird system, having to gather and collect spells just to cast them later, as well as how slow you'd gather the spells. I later learned that the higher your magic stat, the faster your magic gathering would become, and I also learned that magic generally wouldn't be used a lot in normal combat anyways, so you'd rarely touch your huge pile of magic spells unless a boss or healing.  What really makes me like this system is equipping the spells to your stats, since the more magic you have of that type you're attaching to a specific stat (maximum 100 stack of any spell), the higher boost that stat would recieve. It also takes into account what kind of magic is being placed onto the stat, so placing something like... haste onto your speed stat would give it a massive boost. Casting spells equipped to your stats would cause that stat to lower, due to a smaller stack being there now, so you might end up finding a use for many spells you'd never even give the chance in other FF games.  I've personally only played FF4, 5, 6, and 7 (as well as this game), but I find this manages to be my second favourite, even beating out games I have a nostalgic feeling for. A well-written and interesting story, wonderful soundtrack (even though I think this port has a different one, but I haven't heard the original), and a cast of characters I ended up warming up to the same as the protagonist. If you haven't played this, I strongly recommend you give it a try if you're into 'turn-based' RPGs, since it was a wonderful experience for only $12.

Final Fantasy VIII works hard to address a lot of the design issues present in the previous game - save points are present in better locations, the world map now has roads you can travel to avoid constant enemy encounters, the tutorials are detailed (in some cases too-detailed), the minigames are less frustrating.  In saying that, the game is technically poorer than the PS1 version in terms of both visuals and audio. The soundtrack is good, but it's no FFVII, and the cheap midi sounds are jarring when compared to the PS1 version. The pre-rendered backgrounds have very low resolution, and the characters stand out starkly against the world around them. The greater articulation and realism given to the character models is a blessing and a curse - their gestures are much more varied and identifiable, but the stylised actions and humour of the characters clashes with the life-like designs. The cuteness of FFVII's characters allowed a sense of humour and slapstick that doesn't comfortably carry over into this more realistic design, and leaves some moments feeling awkward, as if the designers couldn't quite meet the goal they were aiming for.   In contrast to FFVII, the game world opens up almost immediately, and rewards the player generously in terms of money. The 'Junction' system of battle is quite confusing to begin with, and may be prohibitively overwhelming for those with little patience, but once one learns the ins and outs of the system, the variation it allows makes the FFVII system feel like button-mashing child's play. The abolition of 'magic points', in favour of 'drawing' spells from the enemy and the environment is a refreshing change, and makes the battles feel less restrictive as you can more-or-less cast away to your heart's content, rather than constantly worrying about refilling the MP bar.   One feature I don't quite like is effectively making the summoned Guardians a default attack - watching their stunningly cinematic (and lengthy) attacks is fun for the first few times, but gets really tedious after a while, to the point that I could set one attack for each character, and then surf the web while all the cinematics played.   All in all, the gameplay is a noticable improvement over FFVII, although it comes a distant second in terms of audio-visual quality. Hopefully these issues are addressed at some point, but who knows. It doesn't kill the game for me, and FFVIII is much easier to pick up and play than its predecessor, but they are both worthy additions to the series, and were iconic games of their time.

Story – 1/5 -> 20%  The story is the typical “defeat the evil mastermind who threatens the life of the entire planet” type of story. However, it is also incredibly convoluted and filled with many plot holes. If you finished listening to some NPC's explanation about what is going on and still have no clue who's side they are on, then the story is too convoluted for its own good. The one redeeming quality is that the main characters are well-defined. You could easily identify with the main character, Squall.  Graphics – 4/5 -> 80%  The graphics are much improved over the horrible graphics of the previous game. Some parts of the game still have rough edges, like a few of the character models, but for the most part, you shouldn't really notice any problems (at least for graphics of its time). In particular, the FMVs look spectacular and flow smoothly with the rest of the game.  Sound – 5/5 -> 100%  None of the music or sound effects felt out of place. Of particular note is the boss theme music which provided an appropriate adrenaline rush.  Controls – 9/10 -> 90%  Even if you have a problem with the default controls, it is possible to redefine them, and none of the extra ways the main controls were used for “minigames” felt awkward or misused. The only problem I experienced was that the overworld was incredibly disorienting to navigate without the map open.  Resources – 5/5 -> 100%  Unlike the Playstation version, this version of FFVIII comes with Chocobo World without the need for a Pocketstation. This provides an extra source for items beyond the main game. Even if you choose not to abuse Chocobo World, FFVIII provides plenty of ways to keep your stats in tip-top shape.  One interesting resource system in this game is the SeeD rank. Depending on your rank, you will be paid a certain amount as you walk around the world. The higher your rank, the more you are paid. There are a variety of ways to increase your rank, including monster kills and several sidequests. This ensures you don't have to always face monsters to grind for gold if you don't want to.  Player Growth – 3/5 -> 60%  FFVIII's unique system is the Junctioning system. Summon spirits are called Guardian Forces, or GF, which can be linked to particular characters to give them new abilities. GFs can be taught new abilities for your characters to use as well as slots for particular stats in order to boost them with magic.  In addition, enemies level with you, in order to attempt to balance the game. However, the game is not very well balanced for both newcomers and veterans alike, as leveling up too much tends to make the game more difficult, and it is possible to obtain late game magic spells at the beginning in order to boost your stats ridiculously high.  Learnability – 4/5 -> 80%  The game regularly provides the option to view a tutorial on various game mechanics. Unfortunately, it can be rather invasive when you are given a chance later in the game to view a tutorial of a concept you have already been taught.  One feature of note is the SeeD Test. In addition to increasing your SeeD rank, tests also provide a way to test your knowledge of the game mechanics. The tests can prove to be a nice refresher if you forget anything, since you can view them at any time.  Difficulty - 12/15 -> 80%  The game initially provides a nice blend of challenging gameplay. However, it does not provide enough challenging end-game content. There is a super boss, but it is easy to defeat compared to other Final Fantasy games with super bosses.  Entertainment – 38/40 -> 95%  While the game is not very challenging overall, the Junction system still makes the gameplay very enjoyable.  Replay value – 3/5 -> 60%  As with most single player games, there is not much incentive to play the game again, especially if the story hurts your head. However, the Junction system provides many different ways to approach boss fights. It can be interesting to experiment with different approaches and create your own challenge runs.  Total – 84/100 -> 84%  I would recommend at least giving the game a try if you have never played this game before on the Playstation. It is very fun to experiment with the Junction system and different magic spells. If you have played the Playstation version and you are a completionist, you might still want to buy the PC version for the inclusion of Chocobo World.

+ Great nostalgic value + Vast open world with lots of secrets + Plethora of side quests + Triple Triad + Chocobo World + The junction system provides a wide variety of customization + A story revolving around captivating characters + Great soundtrack + Great designs  - Re-release of the first PC port of the game - Last decade's controller support didn't transition well into this decade - Low quality audio files - Graphic enhancements are hard to notice (if there really are any) - No wide screen support (instead, it stretches the screen) - Drawing magic - The game often unjunctions characters other than Squall and there's no preset options - World feels generic - Lore and events are confusing - requires A LOT of modding  Verdict: FFVIII was a great game back then and the one that introduced me to the franchise, no less. It holds a huge sentimental value to me and I bet to many others. It can still be enjoyable for newer generations, but the gameplay didn't transition well into this decade and Square Enix didn't care to enhance the game properly. For those unaware, this is a re-release of the 2000 port of the original released for the PlayStation. It doesn't improve much, if at all, over the first port and it can be a huge let down for people used to the PS2 gameplay mechanics onwards. For those familiar with the storytelling of FFX and above, VIII might also feel lacking in that department as the world feels very shallow with little history. None of this, however, means is not worth it. The player, epsecially if new, just has to dive into with an open mind and understand that yes, it's a very dated game. Modding the game (check the guides for a list of mods) can help with the experience and bring a twist to the nostalgia seekers.   A note on the DRM:  Is not REALLY a DRM. Steam DOES NOT require your to have a Square Enix account to save your progress and register achievement progress. The Square Enix account is optional and the lack of it won't get in the way of your game progress. The problem with this is that the launcher is constantly reminding the player to login, but you don't HAVE to. If you already have a Square Enix account linked to your Steam account, you won't even notice this, not in VIII, not in other Square Enix games that make use of their social network.

We didn't have a console growing up because my parents got addicted (HA!) and decided to get rid of it, and we were always just alittle behind with the technology to play the newest stuff on PC; I would hang out with friends and watch them play or play on their systems. This game we got when we finally had a PC then that could play it, and it was first time I played an RPG like this (although Zork Grand Inquisitor is my ultimate fave, there are differences here). This game is not something you can really bust your way through. It takes time to properly level your characters; you have to collect magic by either drawing it out from enemies or going around buying it, and I loved the concept that you could run out of the number of spells you had as opposed to mana; you have to really play through the environment to get the full experience. Okay, well, you can get through it faster by just sticking to the main story, but there are a lot of fun side stories and puzzles and bosses to deal with.  Story wise, it's another romance tale, but I think Square Enix does them pretty well. You gave a broody, emo, angry male lead, Squall, but you learn why he's like that as you go on in the story. You're not really supposed to like him all that much until his character is further revealed, in my opinion. You have a bubbly, romantic, but motivated young female lead, who has other sides to her revealed as well. There's time traveling involved, and just don't focus on thinking about it too much because the storyline as a whole that involves a few twists and turns when a powerful sorceress makes a move on the world these characters inhabit is pretty interesting. It's character based too, and you tend to fall in love with a lot of them.   The dynamics of gameplay is that you can design a your core group with up to 3 play playable characters. If you're not into custamizing characters often, might not be your thing, but they have a neat auto option that you can select and it does all the hard work for you. Combat is turn based, and it's not timed. I kind of like that, and it's almost more like chess (umm, just not the timed kind, I suppose). You can also collect guardian forces (GFs), which are powerful magical monsters that you can call upon and level up to create devastating attacks. Magic is, as previously stated, a collection game, and the most annoying thing can be spending hours fighting enemies to collect magic because stores sometimes only carry a certain amount of some magics. However, if you're into that kind of long haul game, it shouldn't bother you.   If you're picking up this game as someone part of the new generation or just having gotten into gaming in today's age, you might think the graphics a bit backwards, but they were pretty spectacular from that time, and I still find them rather breathtaking. Cut scenes are pretty awesome and cinematic, as Square does. Also, I've heard the music for the game when bought and played through Steam is the midi stuff, and not the actual musical score originally played with. It's not that big of a turn off in my opinion, but might be for you, but for the price that FFVIII usually goes for, I'd say it's worth it to try and see. You can easily purchase the phenominal orchestra score on any web sites like amazon for example - and I highly recommend that (there is also a full piano album!).   All in all, I highly recommend giving this game a try, especially if you are a fan of the RPG genre and haven't been able to play some of these older titles.

Ahh... Final Fantasy VIII. The great divider. Some people love it, some people hate it, some people  really  hate it.  Final Fantasy VII and VIII were the first (and for many years, the only) Final Fantasy games released on the PC. This version is very similar, and likely based on, the original PC port released in 2000. Final Fantasy VIII was the first in the series for me, I played it near to its PC release, when I was 17, and have since finished it about 9 or 10 times. It is not a great game, but it's not bad, by any stretch of the imagination. It has flaws, but as a complete package, it's a very enjoyable experience.  Most of the criticism for this game comes from the kitschy story and the terrible implementation of the Junction system; specifically, the Draw system. This review will cover those systems.  On paper, the Junction system is phenomenal; and it completes the process Final Fantasy VII began with Materia affecting character stats. Simply put, the Junction system allows you to directly link a spell to a character stat. Life magic linked to your HP stat will give you more health, and strong magic such as Triple or Ultima will provide huge bonuses to various other stats.  The system really shines in its Status and Elemental Attack and Defence junctions, which allow you to link a Status spell (such as Sleep, Drain and Blind) and an Elemental spell (such as Fire, Water and Holy) to your weapon attacks and defence:  Linking Fire to your elemental defence will reduce the damage you take from fire spells. Linking higher level spells, such as Fira and Firaga will reduce the damage you take further and eventually even allow you to absorb that damage. As you'd expect, linking Fire to your elemental attack will cause your attacks to deal fire damage, which is a big advantage against monsters weak to fire.  Similarly, linking a Status spell, such as Sleep to your status defence will reduce the likelihood of being affected by that status effect; and eventually, will negate it completely. And naturally, linking a Status spell to your status attack, will cause your attacks to have a chance to afflict the enemy with that effect. This, by the way, also applies to the Death spell, which has a chance to one-shot a non-boss monster.  Holy hell, what a remarkable level of customization! Amazing, right?!  Not quite.  On its own, it is a great system. Unfortunately, it's not on its own. It is joined by the Draw system; which deviated dramatically from the series' norm and drew (get it?) most of the criticism leveled at the game. Prior to (and since) Final Fantasy VIII, magic spells in the series had a cost of MP - that is, mana. Spells were permanently learned (for the most part), a character had a pool of MP, and each spell cost a certain amount. Not so in this game. Final Fantasy VIII's spells existed in a large, but finite, inventory and each of your characters was able to stock 100 of a spell.  Obtaining these spells required you to extract - or 'Draw' - them from your enemies. Stronger enemies yielded stronger spells. And the type of enemy you fought affected the kinds of spells it possessed - for example, enemies in snowy regions were likely to have the Ice spell and its variants on it, aquatic enemies had Water, and so on. Add to this the fact that your characters' magic stat affects the amount of magic you are able to retrieve in any given Draw action. It is entirely possible for you to spend more than an hour drawing between 1 and 5 spells each time. On each character. Three times.  The option to synthesize these spells from various items dropped by enemies, as well as quest rewards and cards from the card minigame is available; but it's fairly clear that enemies were intended as the main source of most spells.  And the grind begins.  Final Fantasy is not a series foreign to grinding, in most other games in the series, this is implemented as the traditional grind for XP and levels; but as those are fixed in Final Fantasy VIII (every single level requires 1000 XP), the grind was shifted to the acquisition of magic.  OK... So far, it's not so bad... Grind is always a thing...  Ah, but what I have yet to mention, however, is that the quantity of the magic you link to your stats affects them directly. The less of a spell you have, the less effective it is. And if you follow along the logic, you'll come to the conclusion that the magic you link - ostensibly, the strongest magic you have - are the ones you are  least likely to want to actually use in combat.  Yep. I can't remember the last time I actually used a spell in combat.  And so, the other shoe drops. Magic, which is one of Final Fantasy's most recognizable aspects and, arguably, quintessential to the nature of the series, is effectively removed from the combat system.  That sounds terrible, doesn't it? Nah, it's not as grim as all that. You get used to it, and the rest of the game absolutely makes up for it. Final Fantasy VIII is not a bad game, it's even a good game. The art is great for its time, the cinematics are awesome and the story is a bit juvenile - maybe a bit more than your average Final Fantasy (or highschool anime for that matter) - but if you're into that, then you'll enjoy it quite a bit. As I have.

I would recommend this game to everyone if I could, but I understand you may not like it as much if you're as hooked on the styles of the other games.

I'll start this off with a bit of context: the first time FF8 rolled around, I did not finish it. In fact, I barely got past the first disk. From what I recall it wasn't necessarily due to any particular fault on the games part as much as it was during a deluge of RPGs and it eventually got lost in the shuffle. As of today, I regret not finishing the story, since I've enjoyed this play-through rather extensively.  While I often would expect to defer to the original PS One version as being the superior, I do feel that this may have been the best possible way to experience the game since there are quite a few nagging details that the PC version helps avoid. The game mechanics are a bit out there as far as FF titles go, and can create a significant amount of time devoted to grinding magic acquisition. It is actually to the point in which I could have blamed my initial reluctance to finish the game on that alone, but at the time that was not a particular obstacle, since I really enjoyed abusing those kinds of mechanics and had no problem spending time setting up goofy ways of making it easier (set the control on memory and do some studying while the game ‘draws’ things for you). In the PC version though you can bump up your stock with a push of a button (F5, by the way) and then go on your way, saving significant amounts time. I would say ‘effort’ as well, but it really isn't hard or complicated, just tedious.  So… is it worth playing if you are circumventing game mechanics? Easily, yes. There is still plenty of other facets to the game that are much less annoying (the card game, GF customization, gathering weapon materials, etc). Boss battles are occasionally interesting and have some quirks, though it probably could have had that occur more often since much of the game is face-roll-on-keyboard(gamepad) easy. It should be noted that like any other PC port of a JRPG, expect to use a controller. It probably could be handled with a keyboard alone, but it is not really made with keyboard and mouse in mind (shocker, I know).  The themes of the game can be pretty quickly summarized as being about an awkward romance (note the specific title silhouette with a couple embracing) involving an introverted male lead and a heroine determined to tease him constantly. They spend some time world-building and such but it is clearly tertiary to the main focus, Rinoa and Squall. That would probably be part of why I hold it in higher esteem than many other FF games in that it achieves this much better then most. The main boss and overall conflict is kind of explained, but not terribly well, but it never feels like it was that important anyway. Admittedly, it could be considered a bit of a cheap way to get a pass regarding some of the most frustrating and goofy aspects of JRPGs in general (the antagonist mainly just be crazy, no real solid motivation or realistic goals), which totally do apply here as well. But, quite frankly, I didn’t really care. I still enjoyed every minute of it.

Every time I played one of the older Final Fantasy games, I always thought that the latest one was 'the best one I ever played.' While time and retrospect has changed my mind on which FF games were the 'best' in my opinion, one thing can be said about FF8: it is still great today.   This title is among the top in the franchise for sheer amount of content. There is plenty to do (including a card game that is still played today outside of this game!), and a whole lot of secrets to find. Also, a variety of different characters and personalities make going through this great journey of self-discovery and saving the world even more enjoyable.  The game play mechanics are actually still among the deepest in the franchise. The 'Junctioning System' allows the player to truly customize their characters game play style in almost every way possible. Players can attach Magic onto every slot in a characters stat-line to increase their potency. Players can even add Magic onto their attack and defense slots to add elemental and status effects onto their attacks (or make them immune to various types of attacks and effects). Conversely, if you don't really understand this system, players can just rely on just casting the powerful Guardian Forces (GF's) throughout the game. This can be repetitive as the animations for these summoned companions cannot be skipped. But, at least you have options.  However, when looking at production values out-of-the-box, this game is certainly dated, and filled with flaws. The pre-rendered backgrounds are hideously blurry and the sound is made up of awful midi-files. Fortunately, the avid gamer can find a fix for all of these issues. Mods exist to clean up the graphics and interface and make them look decent. There are also sound mods to bring the orchestral soundtrack back into the game.  All-in-all, if you've never played FF8, but like JRPG's, this one is certainly worth the play-through. It can be considered essential to fans of the genre. If you already played it back in 1999, I can definitely say it is just as good today (if not better) as it was back then. A lot can change in 17 years, and there are possibly many story elements that you did not understand or certain nuances and poignant moments that could have gone past your head.  9/10 'Excellent'

BUY THE ORIGINAL PS1 VERSION OF THIS GAME IF YOU CAN, IT'S WORTH IT JUST FOR THE MUSIC ALONE. FFVIII is an absolutely great game that gets ripped on too frequently by the few loud FFVII fans that wanted another VII when it came out. Needless to say: ignore them. I'm going to list some gameplay related features that make FFVIII different to other games in the series below, whether these are pros or cons are up to you.  1. THIS GAME IS TURN BASED (ATB). You can configure in-game whether you want turns to wait when you input your commands (like FFX) or whether time will pass regardless, meaning the battle doesn't pause when you in put commands. It's great for RPG beginners or veterans.  2. NO GRINDING NEEDED/ENEMIES LEVEL WITH YOU. I think this is a great feature if you like a challenge. You can stay at a low level and breeze through boss fights or you can level up and make things more challenging for yourself. For those that hate to grind, you'll never have to.  3. LOTS OF CONTENT. FFVIII has the best minigame (triple triad) which is almost like a full game within the game, card fanatics will love it. There is also numerous story-related side-quests, weapons to upgrade, hidden GF's/summons to collect, chocobo minigames and if you love retro-bit games (like tamagotchi or pokewalker) the pocket station is included in this version where you can raise a baby chocobo, collect items and train it to summon in-game.   4. BEST MUSIC. I'm actually not being biased here, in my opinion FFVIII has consistently great music and every battle and boss theme is epic. Sadly the port uses MIDI whereas the original game does not. I had to mod this port because after playing the original game I could not bring myself to listen to the MIDI tracks.  Anyway the best way to judge the game for yourself is to play it yourself, this is my favourite game I love everything about it and I hope you will too!
